properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Prolonged snowfall event expected beginning this evening. Several hours of freezing rain possible overnight for south-central New Brunswick. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm, locally 20 cm. Total Freezing rain: 2 to 5 mm. Maximum wind gusts: 40 to 60 km/h. Locations for snowfall: most of New Brunswick. Locations for freezing rain: south-central New Brunswick. Time span: tonight through Sunday night for snowfall and overnight into early Sunday morning for freezing rain. Remarks: Snow has begun over parts of western New Brunswick this evening and will spread eastward tonight, with strong winds and local blowing snow possible. South-central New Brunswick could see several hours of freezing rain before the change over to rain. Coastal regions along the Fundy shore should remain warm enough for rain with this system. A slight change in the track of the system could affect the snowfall amounts and the duration of freezing rain. The rain-snow line may shift slightly and warnings for snowfall and freezing rain may be required as this system draws nearer. Conditions will improve across the Maritimes on Monday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-13T17:42:08-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-13T01:43:08-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4290201512.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Potential severe winter storm this week. Locations: Southeastern Labrador and northern Newfoundland. Time span: Tuesday into Wednesday. Remarks: A winter storm will affect Newfoundland and Labrador beginning Tuesday. While it is too soon to provide specific details, the potential exists for strong easterly or northeasterly winds, accompanied by significant amounts of snow. Additional information will be provided as the details become more certain. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain mixed with ice pellets and some snow this evening. A band of freezing rain will continue to affect parts of Central and Eastern Ontario this evening, before changing over to plain rain by midnight as milder air arrives from the south. Precipitation may change briefly back to snow by Sunday morning as temperatures cool off to near or below zero again. Hazards: near 5 mm of ice accretion due to freezing rain this evening. Up to 5 cm of snow and ice pellets. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Utility outages may occur. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-13T17:06:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-13T01:07:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1142744405.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Potential winter storm mid week. Locations: Newfoundland. Time span: Tuesday and Wednesday. Maximum wind gusts: westerly 80 km/h with higher gusts likely along coastal areas. Remarks: A storm will track towards Newfoundland Monday night. While it is too soon to provide specific details, the potential exists for strong winds accompanied by significant amounts of snow or rain. Snowfall is expected for western and northern Newfoundland, while mainly rain is expected in the east. Central areas may see a change from snow to rain throughout this event. Additional information will be provided as the details become more certain. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Storm Surge Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Warning of potential breaking sea conditions and overwash issued jointly by Fisheries and Oceans Canada (Science) and the Meteorological Service of Canada - Quebec Region on 2020-12-13. Higher than normal water levels and large waves are expected near the coast on December 13th 2020. An intense low pressure system will cause moderate winds in the below mentioned regions. The combination of these winds and the fact that we are currently in a period of high amplitude tidal range could produce minor flooding along the coast near these localities, on the dates and at the times specified (Eastern Standard Time). Kamouraska - Rivière-du-Loup - Trois-Pistoles: 2020-12-13, from 11:00 AM to 03:00 PM. Rimouski - Mont-Joli: 2020-12-13, from 11:00 AM to 03:00 PM. Matane: 2020-12-13, from 10:30 AM to 02:30 PM. Sainte-Anne-des-Monts - Grande-Vallée: 2020-12-13, from 10:30 AM to 02:30 PM. Forillon Park - Gaspé - Percé: 2020-12-13, from 10:30 AM to 02:30 PM. New-Carlisle - Chandler: 2020-12-13, from 10:30 AM to 02:30 PM. Les Escoumins - Forestville: 2020-12-13, from 10:30 AM to 02:30 PM. Baie-Comeau: 2020-12-13, from 10:30 AM to 02:30 PM. Sept-Îles - Port-Cartier: 2020-12-13, from 10:00 AM to 02:00 PM. ### Coastal erosion is possible in vulnerable areas. Storm surge warnings are issued when water levels pose a threat to coastal regions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-13T21:59:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-13T09:58:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2373012921.2020
Area: Forestville area, Les Escoumins area, Mont-Joli area, Le Bic - Rimouski area, Matane, Grande-Vallée area, Sainte-Anne-des-Monts area, Chandler area, New Carlisle - Port-Daniel area, Forillon National Park - Gaspé area, Percé area, Baie-Comeau, Baie-Trinité area, Sept-Îles - Port-Cartier area, Trois-Pistoles area, Kamouraska area, Rivière-du-Loup area

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and persistent visibility near zero in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Blizzard conditions near the Richardson Mountains. Easterly winds of 100 km/h gusting to 120 are combining with loose snow to reduce visibility to 400 metres or less. This blizzard is expected to last through the weekend. Winds will ease slightly Sunday night but visibility may still be poor in blowing snow. Blizzard conditions will abate early next week. ### Travel is expected to be very difficult or impossible due to near-zero visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High southerly winds with gusts to 90 km/h are expected over this community beginning this afternoon. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-14T01:25:12-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-13T09:26:12-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0667918966.2020
Area: Salluit
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Storm Surge Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Storm surge warning Coastal flood warning issued jointly by Fisheries and Oceans Canada (Science) and the Meteorological Service of Canada - Quebec Region on 2020-12-12. An intense low pressure system will cause moderate winds in the below mentioned regions. The combination of these winds and the fact that we are currently in a period of high amplitude tidal range could produce minor flooding along the coast near these localities, on the dates and at the times specified (Eastern Standard Time). Quebec City: 2020-12-13, from 04:30 PM to 07:30 PM. ### Coastal erosion is possible in vulnerable areas. Storm surge warnings are issued when water levels pose a threat to coastal regions. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-14T01:56:28-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-13T09:57:28-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3685938241.2020
Area: Québec area, Côte-de-Beaupré - L'Île d'Orléans area, Bellechasse area, Lévis area
properties.Author: Environment Canada
